setup.question: Generally, which of the following best describes Brian's character?

Text.text: When we are first introduced to Brian, he is talking to his assistant, Pete, before leaving work for the day:

He is a matter-of-fact person. When barking orders, he doesn't do it meekly, his instructions are plain and practical. He's not the most persistent as he is leaving to make his assistant finish the job for the day. As he leaves, he is oblivious to whatever non-work related statements Pete is trying to tell him and by extension, ignorant of basically everything outside his work.
I think both teams can agree that Brian is dutiful however, he is very persistent as well, as proven by his dedication to his research

he is also definitely meek when it comes to the rebel woman who he finds in his bed, getting flustered easily when she comes but still following her along, despite her being for the opposing cause. His persistence is only furthered when he shoots down a police jet when he could have just left with the rebel
He could have run but instead he chose to stay and fight.

Quotes from A definitely make him seem not meek, and "barely heard remarks" is pretty oblivious. I also don't think B's first quote really shows persistence. B doesn't give quotes for meekness either, and the last quotes are very unconvincing regarding persistence. One more turn in case B can show that A's quotes are super out of context or something, otherwise will end at 99 next turn most likely.

B ignores critical context:
First quote: B leaves out that Brian wondered
. This is more akin to voluntary obliviousness. B also tries to paint this as dedication while leaving out the fact that after wondering

. This is clearly not persistent.
Second quote: B tries to say that Brian could have just fled, but this isn't true as
. Causing an avalanche is evidence of practicality as he applies scientific principles to solve the problem
. He found the best solution to an immediate problem. This is evidence of practicality.
wait no - this man built his entire city
his research has been integral to Venus Inc, he's been persistently researching for so long that he cant fathom why others wouldnt be as invested in his work. Upon discovering a woman in his bed
the meek man is nervous at the sight of the

Brian is not only dutiful but has been incredibly persistent in his work, further, his shyness is expressed when he sees the blonde lady. A also provides maybe one quote - i would be wary of buying into their unsupported story.

I have no idea what "a complexion suitable for painting fire plugs" means...Additionally, B you say "the meek man is nervous at the sight of ...." - but that quote itself isn't actually doing the work! If the quote was "he was nervous at the sight of her hair", you would have quoted the part where it says/indicates he was nervous! 

There's also a tension between meekness and the way B describes his persistence....shooting down a helicopter and being a "man of action" as it seems he is in the later part of the story is evidence against meekness, and in favor of practicality. 

I feel like there's decent evidence in favor of both practicality and persistence - can we focus on meekness vs. obliviousness? Is there any more evidence either way?
On obliviousness, after leaving work, the police do routine checks for rebels. He assures the cop.
Then, once he leaves thinks
. he could see his bed

. He is more concerned about his bath than realizing a person of interest broke into his apartment. He is completely oblivious to everything outside of the task he is currently doing, whether that be his work or taking a bath.
he says he has no rebels because he hasnt seen the girl yet

judge he isnt oblivious - he just didnt see the girl... cause she snuck into his house. This is dumb the man isnt oblivious. Further A didnt argue against any of my quotes regarding his persistence, which means they must not have any ev. to support the latter. FInally, his meekness is characterized by his
this femme fatale clearly makes him nervous. Further A provides little to not ev on his practicality meanwhile I have proven my point extensively.

Ugh I don't feel like learned anything this past turn. I'm pretty confused by A's most recent response. I'm confused why A hasn't argued against meekness more clearly, since the evidence for obliviousness in terms of missing the girl in his apartment isn't very good. This makes me pretty hesitant about A - I'm still leaning there because of the very first argument, but now I'm much less certain. 

B - why didn't you explain wtf "painting fire plugs" means?? Also, if this was the key evidence for meekness, you would have put it in your first argument, instead of the (imo) lackluster 2nd quote about persistence. 

Not learning much more so I'm gonna end the debate.
Well, I guess Brian is dutiful.

B's quote about dedication to research is good evidence for persistence, I feel. However, there's very little to go on for meekness, and A's description does seem to fit the bill for oblivious. Not sure about practicality.

A's point about the avalanche being evidence for practicality seems fair. I'm not really convinced by B's arg regarding meekness.

I'm not sure how to separate persistence from dutifulness.
A's point on obliviousness here seems suspect. But B hasn't really provided any more evidence on meekness here.

answers.reason for outcome: Bs evidence selection was a bit odd. My explanations weren't great but were sufficient.

lmao the judge just seemed mad - but I understand, I accidentally glossed over them wanting to know more about one of my quotes, and since I didnt present it in my first argument it made them skeptical. I think I did a decent job of confusing the judge which probably lead to them being frustrated with the debate which I can empathize with. All in allI following judge direction very explicitly may help ing the future and was probably the reason I lost. Lowkey though a "complexion suitable for painting fireplugs" is a red face I feel like thats not difficult for anyone to deduce and I explicitly mentioned that it made him nervous so not sure why the judge was so confused.
This was a weird/hard one, where I felt like the debaters didn't clash as much as they could have. Overall though I thought the evidence for A was a bit better than B.
Sometimes coin flips go your way
